title: 103_hr698
content: The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" aims to protect Lechuguilla Cave and adjacent public lands from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. Congress recognizes the international scientific and environmental significance of the area and emphasizes the need for public ownership and protection against threats. The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" withdraws Federal lands within the cave protection area from various forms of entry and disposal under public land laws. The cave protection area consists of approximately 6,280 acres in New Mexico. The Secretary of the Interior is required to publish the legal description of the lands in the Federal Register. The Secretary of the Interior will publish the legal description of the lands withdrawn under the "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" in the Federal Register. A detailed map and legal description will be filed with the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the United States Senate and the Committee on Natural Resources of the United States House of Representatives. The map and legal description will be available for inspection at the Bureau of Land Management offices. SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary is prohibited from allowing new drilling on Federal mineral or geothermal leases in the cave protection area until the Record of Decision for the Dark Canyon Environmental Impact Statement is effective. Existing leases can be canceled to protect cave resources, with negotiations for compensation if necessary. The Secretary can cancel existing leases in the cave protection area to protect cave resources, with negotiations for compensation under section 3(a). SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary may limit access to protect Lechuguilla Cave and Federal lands, but existing access to private lands will not be affected. The title does not impact pipelines' right-of-way, maintenance, or construction within the cave protection area. The Act does not affect access to private lands or pipelines' rights within the cave protection area. It does not limit seeking compensation under other laws or defenses available to the United States. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary to carry out this Act are authorized to be appropriated, with funds available only as provided in advance in appropriation Acts.
